column4: How come when you boot into runtime level 1, it doesn't ask for a password (and just gives a root prompt)?
Isn't that a security flaw?
not really, you could as well boot init=/bin/bash and get a root prompt with no password
which works in pretty much all linux dists
why does linux allow that?
because it is a very useful way of doing recovery, without having to bring a boot cd etc
isn't it a security hazard?
well, kind of, but not really. if you want to protect against someone with physical access to the machine, you need to do lots of work, including locking down the bios
well, locking down the BIOS isn't hard
neither is locking down the bootloader to refuse booting anything but the default
how do you do that?
by default neither of this is done, since it is very easy to get into a non-recoverable state
how do you lock down the boot loader?
hm. I don't remember now, I've never done it. but setting a password for grub or so, should be the way to go
ok thanks
is it possible to pass the 'init=/bin/bash' parameter in LILO also without root access?
sure, same thing there. if you want to lock it down, you have to set a password.
and set a bios password, and proper intrusion detection on the hardware.
ok thanks
since it was in here, I just mentioned grub
but in general it is for any bootloader
well, not just set bios password, set bios password and disable anything but internal harddrive boot (no floppy/cd/network/usb/firewire/whatever booting).
